data.event: Washington — By most measures, the $787 billion economic stimulus bill that President Barack Obama signed into law in February appears to be positively flying into the hands of state and local governments.

event.title: will receive $298 million more in the months

data.event: "It's out there," promises Dennis Evans of the Ohio Department of Job and Family Services, who said the state has been notified it will receive $298 million more in the months to come.

event.title: the case of the federal highway transportation funds allocated this week

data.event: In the case of the federal highway transportation funds allocated this week, much of the money has to go through the state budget process before it can be spent.

event.title: will actually be sent out over the next two to three years

data.event: Described as a short-term shot of cash, the money will actually be sent out over the next two to three years, going through some 24 state agencies and, in some cases, going directly to counties and cities.
The state announced earlier this month that it would receive $8.5 million for the Ohio National Guard — money to repair and update antiquated armories, including updating plumbing in Middletown.

event.title: the wire transfer "within the next couple of weeks

data.event: Mark Wayda, a spokesman for the Guard, said it expects to receive the wire transfer "within the next couple of weeks."
That they have to wait for a few more weeks, he said, is nothing – the Guard has been wanting to do these repairs for years.
